>>21643428
uh, would looking into kant be more fruitful? since I think much of hegels base principles spring from that rung, likewise with schopenhaur.

Also, this is me talking from half recollections of the soft concepts I remember rather than anything assuredly posited by hegel:
wouldnt it follow with hegels conception of particulars and absolutes, than any particular, by merit of existing, is real in its own capcity, the issue is moreso how broadly true it is. An analogy would be that a 1 degree angle is real, but a 2 degree angle is more illustrative of the whole, and there are infinite degrees between the 2 angles and above and bellow. so his epistomology is manifestly justified, and becomes more justified the more broadly applicable it becomes, as particulars become less and less narrow.

but this is by no means a definitely hegelin answer, as should be obvious by its lack of rigor or sources, this is just a recollection of some part of the hegelian sentiment that I remembered.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Do people even read literary magazines any more?

Like, Lovecraft earned a semi-decent living (albeit not enough to support himself) from publishing in Weird Tales and several other magazines. His stories received support from other readers, who wrote in to express their enjoyment.

Philip K. Dick also published his stuff in several magazines dedicated to science fiction.

I literally have no idea where people read contemporary stuff now, except for substack, medium and very niche high-brow magazines (e.g., Granta) which are pretty much just echo chambers for MFA grads looking to statpad their CV.

Has the age of the internet, which has destroyed any kind of gatekeepership (good and bad), basically subverted the traditional literary landscape?

I personally have zero interest in reading online.

>Do people even read literary magazines any more?
No. After about five or ten years every single literary magazine either becomes defunct or becomes online-only. This is because every magazine receive 500 times more submissions than they do subscriptions. Most writers don't even know where to send their stories because they've never even heard of the magazines they want to be published in.

You fight tooth and nail to get published somewhere, and when you finally do only five subscribers will actually read your story. And then a few years later when you're gloating about how you're a real published author, everyone answers "oh I never heard of that" and when they look it up online they find out the publication died back in 2003.

>"Fiction," my friend, you will be surprised to discover at last what alarming cousinship it has to Lying: don't go into "Fiction," you Aristos, nor concern yourself with "Fine Literature," or Coarse ditto, or the unspeakable glories and rewards of pleasing your generation; which you are not sent hither to please, first of all! In general, leave "Literature," the thing called "Literature" at present, to run through its rapid fermentations (how more and more rapid they are in these years!), and to fluff itself off into Nothing, in its own way, like a poor bottle of soda-water with the cork sprung; it won't be long. In our time it has become all the rage; highest noblemen and dignitaries courting a new still higher glory there; innumerable men, women and children rushing towards it, yearly ever more. It sat painfully in Grub Street, in hungry garrets, so long; some few heroic martyrs always serving in it, among such a miscellany of semi-fatuous worthless ditto, courting the bubble reputation in worse than the cannon's mouth; in general, a very flimsy, foolish set. But that little company of martyrs has at last lifted Literature furiously or foamingly high in the world. Goes like the Iceland geysers in our time, like uncorked soda-water; and will, as I said, soon have done. Only wait: in fifty years, I should guess, all really serious souls will have quitted that mad province, left it to the roaring populaces; and for any Noble-man or useful person it will be a credit rather to declare, "I never tried Literature; believe me, I have not written anything;" and we of " Literature" by trade, we shall sink again, I perceive, to the rank of street-fiddling; no higher rank, though with endless increase of sixpences flung into the hat. Of "Literature" keep well to windward, my serious friend!—
>"But is not Shakspeare the highest genius?" Yes, of all the Intellects of Mankind that have taken the speaking shape, I incline to think him the most divinely gifted; clear, all-piercing like the sunlight, lovingly melodious; probably the noblest human Intellect in that kind. And yet of Shakspeare too, it is not the Fiction that I admire, but the Fact; to say truth, what I most of all admire are the traces he shows of a talent that could have turned the History of England into a kind of Iliad, almost perhaps into a kind of Bible. Manifest traces that way; something of epic in the cycle of hasty Fragments he has yielded us (slaving for his bread in the Bankside Theatre); and what a work wouldn't that have been! Marlborough said, He knew no English History but what he had got from Shakspeare; and truly that is still essentially the serious and sad fact for most of us; Fact thrice and four times lamentable, though Marlborough meant it lightly. Innumerable grave Books there are; but for none of us any real History of England, intelligible, profitable, or even conceivable in almost any section of it!
—Thomas Carlyle, Shooting Niagara, § VI, ¶¶ 5–6

From Sir Roger Scruton’s book “How to be a Conservative”

>Our national narrative may change, but what underlies it is something that remains always in place: the secular law. posts.sub: If Cormac McCarthy wrote about incels.
posts.com:
It was a life of solitude and frustration for the man, an outcast in a world that seemed designed to reject him. He saw himself as superior, a brilliant mind unappreciated by a society that favored the flashy and the shallow. He felt a constant rage simmering within him, a boiling cauldron of frustration that threatened to spill over at any moment.

He spent his days holed up in his small apartment, nursing a deep sense of resentment and anger. He scoured the internet, reading forums filled with like-minded individuals who shared his frustrations and bitterness. He felt a sense of camaraderie with these anonymous strangers, bonding over their shared experiences of rejection and loneliness.

But as much as he wanted to connect with others, he found himself constantly pushing people away. He was consumed by his own self-pity and resentment, unable to form meaningful relationships with anyone. He was an incel, a term he embraced with a sense of pride, even as it pushed him further into the shadows of society.

One day, he snapped. He walked the streets, seething with anger, feeling a sense of powerlessness that he couldn't escape. He saw the couples walking hand-in-hand, the groups of friends laughing and chatting, and he felt a deep sense of jealousy and resentment. He was filled with a desire for revenge, a need to make those who had rejected him pay for their cruelty.

In a moment of rage, he acted out, lashing out at the world that had rejected him. The consequences of his actions were swift and severe, sending shockwaves through the community and leaving a trail of destruction in their wake.

In the aftermath of his outburst, the man was left with nothing but the emptiness of his own loneliness. He was consumed by regret, filled with a sense of hopelessness and despair. He realized too late that his anger and frustration had consumed him, that he had allowed himself to be defined by the hate and bitterness that had driven him to this point.

As he sat in his cell, he realized that he would be forever remembered as an incel, his name synonymous with violence and hate. And in that moment, he understood the true meaning of solitude, of being truly and completely alone in a world that had never truly accepted him.

It’s been a frequent thread in the world’s religious and mystical traditions. See chi (Taoism), prana and kundalini shakti (often just shortened as kundalini) (Hinduism, and sometimes appropriated by some schools of Buddhism, especially Tantric traditions), candali (Tantric Tibetan Buddhism, see ibid, inspired by “kundalini”), mana (Melanesian and Polynesian shamanism and mythology, held to be a vital and supernatural energy/substance pervading the entire universe, and which some can “accumulate” and have more of). Even Christ laying hands on the ill and disabled to heal them, suggests a belief in this type of force or energy, which the 20th-century Christian Science cult took as a core concept and ran with it.

The 20th-century psychologist Wilhelm Reich, who was simultaneously brilliant yet insane, tried to resurrect Mesmeric vitalism with his “orgone energy” theory.

Fun fact: without even being known to have studied Hinduism or Tantra or ever claimed any inspiration from them, Wilhelm Reich’s own eccentric, wayward, self-willed forays into psychology, psychiatry, and medicine, made him come up with a similar functional concept to the “kundalini” of Hindu mystics. Reich tied the orgone energy he saw as permeating and animating the entire universe and especially finely organized in living beings, to what he called “orgastic potency” (or “orgasmic potency”).

posts.name: Possible cult leader
posts.com:
>>21640847
This is the strength of the sexual force, or of the orgasm, of the living being. Yet, although this is one pole orgone energy worked through according to Reich, it also functioned for the general health, well-being, and psychological state of the human being. This is pretty close to esoteric Tantric teachings that the same energy animating and enlivening the human being, and which becomes the energy of “enlightenment” when raised to the head (Sahasrara Chakra at the crown of the skull), at the other pole is sex energy. And that the energy courses from roughly around the genital region and base of the spine, up the spine (central nervous system) and to the brain when kundalini is activated in a person.

If any of you have read or know or care about Gurdjieff, he also had some interesting thoughts on and relation to this theory. He devotes an entire chapter to Mesmer in his “Beelzebub’s Tales to His Grandson,” saying he’s one of the rare humans in modern history to pierce through to a deeper-than-usual insight about the nature of reality, and was of course systematically “henpecked” to symbolic death by the intelligentsia of the day and materialist reductionism of the West.

Several students, who don’t seem to have any reason to be lying, and who worked with Gurdjieff at sometimes very different times and places, hence having no explicit tie with the other disciples and necessary knowledge of what they were saying or happened to them, give accounts of their experiences with Gurdjieff’s “animal magnetism” or unusual parapsychological or energetic phenomena he could cause.

Fritz Peters claimed that after years away from Gurdjieff, in which he (Peters) was drafted to fight in WW2, and got PTSD (or then-called “shell shock” or “battle fatigue” from the experiences) and became extraordinarily depressed, went to meet Gurdjieff in his apartment in France, whereupon Gurdjieff hugged him and called him “my son!”. Then, over coffee in Gurdjieff’s apartment, he suddenly transferred a “violet electric energy” (in Peters’s own mind’s eye), instantaneously rejuvenating him massively and dispelling his depression. He says this event surreally caused Gurdjieff himself to grow noticeably wearier, paler, older, weaker, and frailer in just that brief notice, whereupon Gurdjieff left then came back later somehow himself also rejuvenated again.

>He stared at me again for a second, dropped his cane, and cried out in a loud voice, "My son!". … I helped him retrieve his hat and cane, he put one arm around my shoulders and started to lead me up the stairs, saying: "Don't talk, you are sick."

>When we reached his apartment, he led me down a long hall to a dark bedroom, indicated the bed, told me to lie down, and said: "This your room, for as long as you need it." I laid down on the bed and he left the room but did not close the door. I felt such enormous relief and such excitement at seeing him that I began to cry uncontrollably and then my head began to pound. I could not rest and got up and walked to the kitchen where I found him sitting at the table. He looked alarmed when he saw me, and asked me what was wrong. I said I needed some aspirin or something for my headache, but he shook his head, stood up and pointed to the other chair by the kitchen table. "No medicine," he said firmly. "I give you coffee. Drink as hot as you can." I sat at the table while he heated the coffee and then served it to me. He then walked across the small room to stand in front of the refrigerator and watch me. I could not take my eyes off him and realized that he looked incredibly weary—I have never seen anyone look so tired. I remember being slumped over the table, sipping at my coffee, when I began to feel a strange uprising of energy within myself—I stared at him, automatically straightened up, and it was as if a violent, electric blue light emanated from him and entered into me. As this happened, I could feel the tiredness drain out of me, but at the same moment his body slumped and his face turned grey as if it was being drained of life. I looked at him, amazed, and when he saw me sitting erect, smiling and full of energy, he said quickly: "You all right now—watch food on stove—I must go." There was something very urgent in his voice and I leaped to my feet to help him but he waved me away and limped slowly out of the room.

>He was gone for perhaps fifteen minutes while I watched the food, feeling blank and amazed because I had never felt any better in my life. I was convinced then —and am now— that he knew how to transmit energy from himself to others; I was also convinced that it could only be done at great cost to himself.

>It also became obvious within the next few minutes that he knew how to renew his own energy quickly, for I was equally amazed when he returned to the kitchen to see the change in him; he looked like a young man again, alert, smiling, sly and full of good spirits. He said that this was a very fortunate meeting, and that while I had forced him to make an almost impossible effort, it had been—as I had witnessed—a very good thing for both of us. He then announced that we would have lunch together—alone—and that I would have to drink a "real man's share" of fine old Armagnac.

J. G. Bennett, a much more well-known student of Gurdjieff’s who contributed much to the fleshing out of the worldview and sources of the “Fourth Way”, or Gurdjieff’s teachings, as well as being a surprisingly practically intelligent man, contributing to and working in industrial research and the coal industry, as well as contributing to the niche interdisciplinary field of modern science/philosophy of science, variously called “systems studies,” “systems science,” and “systems philosophy,” has this to say of a similar experience of Gurdjieff somehow immaterially throwing Bennett into an altered and ecstatic state of consciousness for a day after pushing him to his mental and physical limits with the manual labor done at the Prieure by Gurdjieff’s students there:

>Bennett participated in the intensive daily programme of the Prieuré (which I have, to some extent, described in Chapter Two). This involved long days of arduous physical work juxtaposed with psychological exercises and intensive work on the sacred dances and movements All of this took place in an extraordinary state of tension. Bennett records that the food was barely adequate (except on Sundays) and that fasting was sometimes used. After, perhaps, two weeks of this regime Bennett fell ill with dysentery and became progressively weaker. In accord with the “only super-efforts count” ethos of the situation he forced himself on until a morning came when, “shaking with fever and very wretched in myself,” he felt that he had failed. Then

Just as I was saying to myself: “I will stay in bed today,” I felt my body rising. I dressed and went to work as usual, but this time with a queer sense of being held together by a superior Will that was not my own.

An American woman, highly dismissive of Gurdjieff and his followers, nudged an acquaintance and gestured at Gurdjieff from across the room, gawkily and jeeringly telling her friend something like, “This man is something like an insane cult leader from the East, here with his ‘students’ of the organization he’s formed.” Gurdjieff then looked at her, she reports freezing up for a moment, and then … having a legitimate orgasm right at that moment in the restaurant.

Some Central Asian Sufis preserve a similar idea under the name of “kaif,” a type of energy of blessing, which saints and developed Sufis have a greater quantity of, and which can hence reside in their presence, as well as their tombs, graves, grave-cloths places on their tombs to gather such “kaif,” artifacts handled by them, architecture (such as of the Mecca, most notably) etc., and hence be passed on to receptive disciples in that way.

In some parts of some traditions which sometimes talk about ideas similar to Mesmer’s animal magnetism, yeah, you can crudely/short-hand compare it to that modern movement. For instance, the Taoists also traditionally believed male ejaculation/orgasm/loss of semen, depleted the male of vital energy, hence sometimes even urging practices of semen retention (coitus reservatus), in which one can have sex but doesn’t let oneself reach orgasm. Hinduism and Buddhism often enjoin celibacy, including even some Tantric sects — the Tantric ones with the esoteric explanation, preserving the sex energy allows the sexual energy to be redirected from the base of the spine and genital region up the spine/central nervous system to the brain, leading to enlightenment. Tantric sects enjoining celibacy exist just as the more exotic Tantric sects more well-known to the West, following the “vamamarga,” left-hand heterodox path, who allow and sometimes even enjoin sex (such as with use of Tantric consorts).

Mesmer himself did not explicitly tie this vital energy/life-force he called animal magnetism to sexual energy, but the later psychologist Wilhelm Reich tied this almost identical concept, which he named orgone energy, to the orgasm, or sexual energy, as already explained, thus believing sexual potency, vigor, vitality and health was linked to overall psychological and bodily health, youth, and vitality, so whatever increased the patient’s “orgastic potency” (which hence could also be taken as, whatever made the patient’s sex life better) overall made them healthier and could cure both mental and physical illnesses. He also coined the phrase “the sexual revolution.” Hence Reich was more on the vamamarga Tantric wavelength than that of traditions enjoining celibacy. However, he was also a little bit insane (to put it mildly), at least in his later life, which perhaps was tragically compounded by the violent opposition and U.S. government and F.D.A. persecution against him worsening his mental health.

Precedents to the German physician Franz Anton Mesmer’s (1734 - 1815) animal magnetism theory can be found in the works of Paracelsus (c. 1493 - 1591), the Swiss physician, alchemist, lay theologian/mystic, and philosopher of the German Renaissance. Mesmer started in the West/at least officially first publicized the techniques and phenomena of hypnotism, then called “Mesmerism” after him. He claimed to use it to affect both physical and psychological cures of distressed patients. He attributed the mechanism of hypnotism, to a vital energy or life force, “animal magnetism”, in patients, with the stronger and healthier animal magnetism of the doctor/agents having a rejuvenating and salutary effect on the weaker, unhealthier patient(s).

>>21642263
>>21641381
It was named thus because like “magnetism”, it was a mysterious immaterial and invisible force/energy/substance which nevertheless had real-life and observable effects, and “animal” because he theorized it to animate living beings. He seems to have literally conceived of it as a (immaterial/energetic/invisible) “fluid,” similar to how scientists of the day thought the force of magnetism functioned as a sort of fluid (like a liquid or gas) and could be modeled as such, but this is based on a somewhat outdated model of magnetism.

Again, he believed those with greater animal magnetism functioned as the ideal and natural “Mesmerists” and hence could effect cures of patients simply from their greater and healthier stock of “animal magnetism” which they contributed to the patient. He also came up independently with a model and some practices similar to Taoist medical Qigong practices (think acupuncture and the like, but not just that), conceiving health as the free flow of animal magnetism in the body, and ill-health being tied to blockages or obstruction of the animal magnetism at various parts of the body. Hence like such medical Taoist folk practices, aimed to find and break these “blockages”. Wilhelm Reich had a similar yet more modernized idea as “body psychotherapy”, holding that areas of muscular tension in the bodies of neurotic patients could be conceived as psychosomatic “body armor,” these muscle groups often being unnecessarily flexed and tenses, as a sort of subconscious psychic defense, from trauma, as a manifestation of fear/latent anxiety, etc. So he tied the breaking up of “body armor” or unnecessary muscular tension in patients (such as through relaxation techniques he came up with), psychosomatically, to improved mental health, holding it could and should all be part of one same process or system — treating the bodily and mental/emotional parts of the human simultaneously.

Compare this to practices like hathayoga, the yoga of the body and physical postures or “asanas” as they’re called, held to put one’s body in the ideal state for meditation and naturally relax the psyche.

On a track from Rochester to London, a gaunty and scuffy looking old South Asian man, presumably Indian, walked in. Glancing around with no available seat in sight, he sat right on the floor, cross-legged with no shame.

The Englishman, with a voice of disgust and contempt, inquired the Indian man who was now face to face with him, "why are you sitting on the ground in the middle of nowhere?" The Indian man simplely answered, "My dear sir, my legs are worned from my travels and there are no seats to rest om." The Englishman, unsatisfied his explanation, expressed his disapproval. "There are no good reasons for you to sit on this wet and dirty floor. Why what is the difference between you and a dog," said the Englishman.

The Indian man did not answer immediately nor did his expression change. He nodded toward the lady next to the Englishman and asked if she was his wife. The Englishman answered yes. The Indian man asked if he had sexual intercourse with his wife. Flustered but determined, the Englishman repeated his answer. The Indian man, with a sly smile, asked, "If that is your wife and indeed you have sex with her, then what is the difference between you and a dog?"

On the other hand, in the biographies or in other records of the personal utterances of almost all great writers, I find complaints of the pain that noise has occasioned to intellectual men. For example, in the case of Kant, Goethe, Lichtenberg, Jean Paul; and indeed when no mention is made of the matter it is merely because the context did not lead up to it. I should explain the subject we are treating in this way: If a big diamond is cut up into pieces, it immediately loses its value as a whole; or if an army is scattered or divided into small bodies, it loses all its power; and in the same way a great intellect has no more power than an ordinary one as soon as it is interrupted, disturbed, distracted, or diverted; for its superiority entails that it concentrates all its strength on one point and object, just as a concave mirror concentrates all the rays of light thrown upon it. Noisy interruption prevents this concentration. This is why the most eminent intellects have always been strongly averse to any kind of disturbance, interruption and distraction, and above everything to that violent interruption which is caused by noise; other people do not take any particular notice of this sort of thing.

>>21638269
>they're the most entertaining when they're outright antagonizing peoeple at expositions or galleries
For me it was the exact opposite, I found the galleries episodes to be kind of bad - it's very easy to look like the smart one if you edit the video and catch people off guard with insults. Also the general edgyness of those video is aging bad in my opinion - there's clearly some desire to just provoke, with little artistic vision behind it, and most of the criticisms sound like "I have read Nietzsche and you have not".
I started finding it way more interesting after they began with portraits, like Simchowitz, and especially Philip, as they manage to show that these very rich, very powerful art dealer are actual (complex) people. I also think they manage to show a very weird dynamic there, namely that while artists need funds, funders want to be acknowledge as artists by being the ones who are sensible enough to legitimize the "good" art. Also, in general, halfway through the series you start seeing more and more of how Stefan and Kate personal life intertwine with the episodes and the people (Philip basically becomes a family friend, besides being a funder), and I think this raises important questions concerning the relation between art and its context.
Seeing Tarik insulting people or Jini having sex or Kate and Stefan saying that some artist is stupid is kind of boring after that.

No. You're selectively applying conceptual labels to dimish the other anon's arguments because you think physical intimacy is a special category. The theory applies to porn in the same way it applies to any enforced social dynamic in dealing with a client (e.g. going through the professional motions dealing with an asshole, rightly defined as a bad social actor, only to have a boss completely outside the situation punish you for his version of events afterward). You just selectively extrapolate on porn while ignoring social repercussions and individual damage that are broadly applicable.

Specific details make the damage of porn more overt/obvious (e.g. it takes advantage of youthful stupidity, appeals to vainity and superficiality, etc; albeit most, if not all, of those elements apply to the entertainment industry in general anyway) but it isn't a special case when it comes to the theories being discussed. An example of someone being a willing agent in sex work also contradicts that point; there are willing participants in the porn industry who are happy with the fame they attain and feel less alienated and abused than the low level employee in the example above. The problem is the mass proliferation and ease of access of pornography and that's what has to be the focus in order to diminish the negative effects--porn isn't a special category given the theoretical aspects of the discussion.

If Zizek said this, he probably had some source he’d read it in somewhere, however dubious the source, and it could be based on reality because it’s known some of the Nazi regime was interested in occultism, magic, mysticism, the paranormal and strange occult phenomena that might help them win the war, such as when they sent expeditions to Tibet.

“The Occult Roots of Nazism: The Ariosophists of Austria and Germany, 1890–1935” by Nicholas Goodrich-Clarke is said to be a good book on this, but I haven’t read it. “Zen at War” written by Brian Daisetz Victoria is a good book about the militaristic aspects of Zen and historical ties of some of them to supporting the feudalistic Japanese regime and their military, the samurai ideal, etc., which ironically made some of them rather more violent than (generally pacifistic) Buddhism is popularly regarded as being.

However, none of this applies to all Japanese Zen Buddhists or Ch’an and Zen Buddhism at large — incredibly dubious to say it does. Anymore than the Spanish Garduña society reputed to have carried out some of the dirty stuff of the Inquisition on behalf of the Catholic Church, and had a mythos that the Virgin Mary had appeared to and sanctioned it’s founder to start the society, represents all of Catholicism or Catholics. Or, just like Nazism doesn’t reflect on all Germans, or most kooky groups like the Theosophists tied to inspiring some of Nazi occultism and talk about “root-races,” most Theosophists are extremely far from being Nazis
